text: In 1977, for the very first time,
a team of British researchers
successfully fertilized a human
egg in a dish and transplanted
the embryo into the mother's body.
The mother gave birth to a baby
named Louise Brown, who is now almost
40 years old. The doctor who pioneered
the procedure won a Nobel
Prize for it, in 2010. That
procedure is now known as "in vitro
fertilization" or "IVF".
But a lot has changed since Louise
was born. By studying IVF for the past
few decades, scientists have made it
a lot more effective, with fewer
complications and better success
rates. There are all kinds of reasons
